choices.text: Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available
Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.text: A woman in labour presented to the ER. A vaginal breech delivery was planned for her. What statement regarding the management is false? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

The statement that breech presentation identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery is false.

 

Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is not automatically a contraindication for a vaginal breech delivery. It is crucial to assess the situation carefully, considering the skill of the obstetrician and the facilities available, but it does not universally rule out the possibility of a vaginal breech delivery.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available: This is correct because the presence of a facility for emergency cesarean section is essential for managing unexpected complications during a breech delivery.

 

Option C. Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor: This is correct because continuous fetal heart rate monitoring is crucial to detect any signs of fetal distress during a breech delivery.

 

Option D. Should be done by a skilled obstetrician: This is correct as vaginal breech deliveries should be performed by an experienced and skilled obstetrician to manage the potential risks and complications effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breech presentation identified for the first-time during delivery is not an automatic contraindication for vaginal delivery, provided other criteria are met and facilities are available.

 

Ref: Page no 449, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text:
Among the given statements, which one would lead you to consider primary amenorrhea as a possibility? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age
  2. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche
  3. High levels of TSH and short stature
  4. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation in a girl who has not attained menarche by a certain age or who lacks secondary sexual characteristics. Specifically:

 

1. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age: This is a classic indicator of primary amenorrhea, particularly if secondary sexual characteristics have developed. It is an age by which menstruation should have started if there are signs of puberty.

 

2. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche: Thelarche, or breast development, typically occurs around ages 9 to 13. If menarche has not occurred within 3 years after thelarche, it is a reason to investigate primary amenorrhea.

 

4. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age: The absence of breast development by age 13 indicates a delay in puberty and warrants evaluation for primary amenorrhea if menstruation has not begun by this age.

 

Other Option:

 

3. High levels of TSH and short stature: While high TSH and short stature may indicate thyroid dysfunction or other endocrine issues, they are not direct indicators of primary amenorrhea. These findings might contribute to secondary causes of amenorrhea or other growth disorders but are not themselves diagnostic criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea should be considered if there is failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age, failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche, or failure of breast development by 13 years of age.

choices.text: Sensory level is from T10 to L1
Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8
In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1
In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding innervation of the uterus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8

 

Explanation:

 

The incorrect statement regarding the innervation of the uterus is option B. Uterine contractility is primarily mediated by hormonal mechanisms rather than by specific spinal innervations. Hormones such as estrogen, prostaglandins, and oxytocin play a significant role in inducing uterine contractions, while progesterone helps maintain uterine relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensory level is from T10 to L1: The sensory innervation of the uterus is indeed from spinal levels T10 to L1. These afferent fibers enter the spinal cord via the inferior hypogastric plexus and are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the uterus.

 

Option C. In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1: During the 1st stage of labor, pain is mediated by spinal segments T10 to L1. This pain is due to the distension of the cervix and lower uterine segment, as well as the contraction of the uterus.

 

Option D. In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction: In early labor, pain is usually related to uterine contractions, which stimulate nociceptors in the genital tract and can cause discomfort and pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine contractility is not mediated by innervations from spinal level T7 - T8; instead, it is primarily influenced by hormonal mechanisms.

 

 

Ref: Page 500, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: What will be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone in low ovarian reserve? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) <1

 

Explanation:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein produced by the granulosa cells of small pre-antral follicles. It serves as a marker for ovarian reserve, reflecting the remaining egg supply in the ovaries.

 

  • AMH in Low Ovarian Reserve: In cases of low ovarian reserve, the AMH level will be less than 1 ng/mL. This indicates a diminished number of remaining follicles and a reduced capacity for fertility.
  • AMH in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Women with PCOS typically have increased levels of AMH due to the presence of a higher number of small antral follicles.

 

Tests for Ovarian Reserve

 

  1. Biochemical Tests:
    • FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone): Levels measured on Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle are increased in poor ovarian reserve.
    • Estradiol: Day 2 levels are increased in poor ovarian reserve.
    • Inhibin B: Levels are reduced in poor ovarian reserve.
    • AMH: Levels are reduced in poor ovarian reserve.
  2. Ultrasound:
    • Antral Follicle Count (AFC): Done on day 2 or 3 of the cycle. The total number of visible follicles are counted. An AFC greater than 10 is considered normal.
  3. Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test: This test evaluates ovarian reserve by measuring FSH levels before and after administration of clomiphene citrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1-4: Levels of AMH within this range might be seen in women with a moderate ovarian reserve. It is not indicative of low ovarian reserve.

 

Option C. >7: High levels of AMH are often associated with PCOS, where there is an increased number of small antral follicles.

 

Option D. >10: Extremely high AMH levels are usually seen in conditions like PCOS and do not indicate low ovarian reserve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) levels less than 1 ng/mL are indicative of low ovarian reserve.

 

Ref: Page 437, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kallman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Kallman syndrome is a condition of hypothalamic hypogonadism that presents as primary amenorrhea with anosmia. It does not cause secondary amenorrhea.

 

Causes of secondary amenorrhea:

 

  • Sheehan's syndrome: This is a condition where the pituitary gland is damaged due to severe blood loss during or after childbirth, leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Asherman's syndrome: This condition involves the formation of scar tissue in the uterine cavity, often as a result of surgical procedures like dilation and curettage (D&C), leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Turner mosaic: This refers to a form of Turner syndrome where some of the cells have the typical 45,X karyotype and others have a different karyotype (e.g., 46,XX). It can lead to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Premature ovarian failure: This condition occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before age 40, causing secondary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner's mosaic: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to ovarian insufficiency.

 

Option C. Sheehan's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to pituitary damage.

 

Option D. Asherman's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to uterine scarring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kallman syndrome is a cause of primary amenorrhea due to hypothalamic hypogonadism and anosmia. Secondary amenorrhea can be caused by conditions such as Sheehan's syndrome, Asherman's syndrome, Turner mosaic, and premature ovarian failure.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg375

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who is being treated for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin presented with complaints of sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness. The finding of the ultrasound is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG  2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

The given clinical situation and USG showing enlarged ovaries having large cysts points to diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

 

OVARIAN HYPERSTIMULATION SYNDROME

 

  • OHSS is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation.
  • The clinical features appear about 3–6 days after the ovulating dose of hCG is administered.
  • Pathophysiology - Increased capillary permeability leads to leakage of fluid from the peritoneal and ovarian surfaces. Variety of chemical mediators like cytokines, Variety of chemical mediators like cytokines.

 

 

 

Management - The management of OHSS is mainly supportive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polycystic ovarian syndrome: PCOS is characterized by chronic anovulation, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries, but it does not typically present with sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness associated with enlarged ovaries having large cysts as seen in OHSS.

 

Option C. Theca lutein cysts: These cysts are associated with molar pregnancies and multiple gestations, often presenting with high levels of hCG but not typically with the acute symptoms and clinical scenario described here.

 

Option D. Granulosa cell tumor: This is a type of ovarian tumor that does not present with the acute symptoms and ultrasound findings characteristic of OHSS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation, with symptoms including abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness, often visible on ultrasound as enlarged ovaries with large cysts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. On performing further investigations, intramural fibroids of sizes 7x5cm and 5x3cm were seen at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was found to be normal. What is the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic Myomectomy

 

Laparoscopic Myomectomy:

 

  • Indications for myomectomy in a woman with infertility and fibroid uterus include:
    • Submucous fibroids of any size/location as they interfere with fertility and pregnancy outcomes.
    • Intramural fibroids that:
      • Distort the endometrial cavity.
      • Are larger than 5 cm in size.
  • In this case, the patient has significant intramural fibroids (7x5 cm and 5x3 cm), making laparoscopic myomectomy the appropriate management to improve fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: This procedure is not indicated for women who wish to conceive as it can compromise uterine function and future fertility.

 

Option C. Artificial reproductive techniques: While ART could be considered in cases of bilateral tubal block, myomectomy should be done prior to potentially relieve the tubal block, improve ART outcomes, and enhance pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option D. GnRH analogues: GnRH analogues are not suitable for this patient as she is eager to conceive. These are typically used for temporary symptom relief or to shrink fibroids preoperatively, but not as a primary treatment for infertility in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic myomectomy is indicated for intramural fibroids larger than 5 cm in women with infertility, as it can improve fertility and pregnancy outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s textbook of gynecology, 8th edition

questions.text: Identify the given instrument: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Outlet forceps

 

Explanation:

 

This instrument is Wrigley’s (Outlet) Forceps.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kielland’s Forceps: Slight pelvic curve, rotational forceps

 

Option B. Pipers Forceps: After coming head of breech, reverse pelvic curve, long parallel shanks for the body to rest on

 

Option D. Das Forceps: It is an Indian type of long Obstetric forceps, lighter than its western counterparts, may be available with axis traction device

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wrigley's (Outlet) Forceps are used for assisted vaginal delivery when the fetal head is at the perineum.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8thedition page 652,659

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman experiences a 2-year history of infertility, as well as experiencing dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and is sensitive in the Douglas pouch. What should be the subsequent course of action in her management? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TVS

 

In this case, the initial step in the diagnostic evaluation of suspected endometriosis is transvaginal ultrasound (TVS). TVS is the first-line imaging modality used to assess pelvic structures and identify abnormalities such as endometriomas or nodularity in the pouch of Douglas. While laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis and allows for direct visualization and biopsy, it is generally reserved for cases where non-invasive methods are inconclusive or when surgical intervention is planned. TVS provides valuable initial information and helps in guiding further diagnostic and therapeutic steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Although laparoscopy is the definitive diagnostic procedure for endometriosis, it is not typically the first step. TVS is preferred initially to assess the presence of endometriosis-related changes and determine if more invasive procedures are necessary.

 

Option B. Laparotomy: Laparotomy is a more invasive surgical approach generally reserved for cases requiring larger abdominal incisions or when laparoscopy is not feasible. It is not typically used as an initial diagnostic tool for endometriosis.

 

Option C. HSG (Hysterosalpingography): HSG is used primarily to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes and uterine cavity. While it can assess tubal factor infertility, it does not provide information specific to endometriosis or the pelvic structures affected by it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of suspected endometriosis is to perform transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) to evaluate pelvic structures and identify abnormalities.

questions.text: A patient with O negative and husband B positive delivered a baby. Has received anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks. In which of the following conditions will you give anti-D post-delivery? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Baby +ve, DCT -ve

 

In cases where an Rh-negative mother has delivered a baby, the administration of anti-D immunoglobulin post-delivery is crucial if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative.

 

  • Rh incompatibility: The Rh-negative mother may develop antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells if fetal-maternal hemorrhage occurs. To prevent this alloimmunization and protect future pregnancies, anti-D immunoglobulin is given to neutralize any fetal Rh-positive red blood cells that might have entered the maternal circulation during delivery.
  • Direct Coombs Test (DCT): This test checks whether antibodies are already attached to the baby's red blood cells. A negative DCT indicates that the fetal RBCs are free of maternal antibodies. If the DCT is negative and the baby is Rh-positive, anti-D is administered to the mother to prevent the formation of antibodies in her system.

 

The administration of anti-D within 72 hours of delivery is standard practice to ensure that any fetal red blood cells in the mother’s circulation are neutralized, thereby preventing Rh sensitization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baby O negative, DCT negative: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of isoimmunization

 

Option B. Baby O negative, DCT positive: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of iso immunization

 

Option C. Baby Positive, DCT positive: In this patient although the Baby is Rh positive , but DCT is positive which means Abs have already formed in the mother and hence there is no use of giving her Anti D

 

Educational Objective:

 

Administer anti-D immunoglobulin to an Rh-negative mother after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative to prevent Rh sensitization and protect future pregnancies.

questions.text: A lady who is 38 weeks pregnant comes to the OPD for a routine checkup. She has a history of normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago. What is her gravida and para score? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G2P1

 

Explanation:

 

  • The obstetric score is used to summarize the past obstetric history as follows:
    • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
    • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
    • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages
    • L - Living children.
  • The GTPAL system includes the following:
    • Gravida
    • Term (>37 weeks)
    • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
    • Abortions (<20 weeks)
    • Number of living children

 

Obstetric Score

 

  • Gravidity:
    • G2 (Second pregnancy)
  • Parity:
    • P1 (One previous pregnancy reaching viability, twins count as one para)

 

So, the correct obstetric score for this lady is G2P1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gravida denotes the number of pregnancies, and para denotes the number of pregnancies reaching the period of viability. Twins count as one in the para score, and the current pregnancy is included in gravida but not in para until delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 469, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: 15-year-old girl with wide-spaced nipples, short height, and the following karyotype: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome


Turner syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of only one X chromosome (45, X) rather than the typical two sex chromosomes (XX or XY). The karyotype shown confirms the absence of the Y chromosome and only one X chromosome, which is diagnostic of Turner syndrome. Clinical features often include short stature, wide-spaced nipples, webbed neck, and other physical anomalies. Turner syndrome is a common genetic condition tested in exams due to its distinctive features and significant clinical implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome in males (47, XXY). It does not fit the description of a 15-year-old girl with the specific karyotype shown and is not associated with the physical characteristics described.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome is characterized by trisomy 21 (an extra chromosome 21) and typically presents with distinct facial features, intellectual disability, and other health issues. The karyotype shown does not match Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Partial mole: A partial mole is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease involving an abnormal pregnancy with an extra set of paternal chromosomes, often presenting with symptoms related to pregnancy and abnormal placental tissue rather than the clinical features described here.

 

Educational Objective:


Turner syndrome is characterized by the karyotype 45,X, and typical clinical features include short stature and wide-spaced nipples, commonly seen in females.

questions.text: The type of pelvis commonly associated with occipitoposterior and face to pubis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 

 

 

The anthropoid pelvis is characterized by a larger anteroposterior diameter compared to its transverse diameter, giving it a vertical oval shape. This type of pelvis is commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern, where the baby's face presents toward the pubic symphysis during delivery. The anthropoid shape often causes the baby's head to rotate into a posterior position, leading to a higher likelihood of occipitoposterior presentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gynecoid pelvis: The gynecoid pelvis is the typical female pelvis with a round shape and balanced anteroposterior and transverse diameters. It is most favorable for vaginal deliveries and is not commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions.

 

Option B. Android pelvis: The android pelvis is heart-shaped, narrower, and typically has prominent ischial spines. It is more commonly associated with obstructed labor and deep transverse arrest rather than occipitoposterior or face to pubis presentations.

 

Option D. Platypelloid pelvis: The platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a very wide transverse diameter and a flat shape, which often leads to delayed engagement of the fetal head. It is not associated with occipitoposterior positions but can lead to asynclitism and face presentations.

 

Educational Objective:


The anthropoid pelvis is the pelvic type most commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern.

choices.text: Medroxy progesterone acetate

questions.text: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple hysterectomy

 

For postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia of the endometrium, the recommended treatment is a total hysterectomy. This approach is taken due to the increased risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma, especially given the presence of atypia and the patient's postmenopausal status.

 

  • Simple Hysterectomy: This involves the surgical removal of the uterus and is considered the ideal treatment for postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia to prevent the progression to cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: This is a progestogen treatment used primarily for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, especially in women who desire to preserve fertility. It is not the ideal treatment for atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman.

 

Option C. Levonorgestrel: The Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) is used for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia and as a conservative treatment for women wishing to preserve fertility. However, it is not the treatment of choice for atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy: This is not a standard treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. It is typically reserved for more advanced or inoperable endometrial cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, the ideal treatment is a total hysterectomy to prevent progression to endometrial carcinoma.

 

Ref: Page no 330, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to given drug? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malpresentation of fetus

 

Explanation:

 

The given drug in the image is Oxytocin, which is commonly used to induce or augment labor. However, its use is contraindicated in several conditions to avoid complications during childbirth. One such contraindication is malpresentation of the fetus, where the fetus is not in a head-down position, potentially complicating a vaginal delivery.

 

Contraindications to Oxytocin:

 

  • Grand multipara: Women who have given birth five or more times.
  • Contracted pelvis: A pelvis that is too small to allow the passage of the fetus.
  • History of Classical Cesarean Section: Classical C-sections involve a vertical incision in the uterus, increasing the risk of uterine rupture.
  • History of 2 or more Lower Segment Cesarean Sections (LSCS): Multiple C-sections also increase the risk of uterine rupture.
  • Malpresentation: Includes breech, transverse, or any non-cephalic presentation of the fetus.
  • Obstructed labor: Labor that does not progress due to physical obstruction.
  • Fetal distress: Signs that the fetus is not well, such as abnormal heart rate patterns.
  • Hypovolemia: Reduced blood volume in the mother, which can complicate the use of oxytocin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart disease in mother: Heart disease in the mother is considered a relative contraindication for oxytocin administration. It requires careful monitoring and assessment by the healthcare provider, but it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option C. Premature labour: Oxytocin can sometimes be used to manage labor in preterm situations under strict medical supervision. It is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is not a contraindication for the use of oxytocin. Proper management of hypothyroidism is necessary during pregnancy, but it does not specifically preclude the use of oxytocin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is contraindicated in malpresentation of the fetus, grand multipara, contracted pelvis, history of classical cesarean, history of 2 or more LSCS, obstructed labor, fetal distress, and hypovolemia.

 

Ref: Page no 573, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 226th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presented to OBG department at 36 weeks of amenorrhea. Ultrasound shows that the fetus is in a transverse lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no gross anomaly. Both her previous deliveries were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External cephalic version

 

In this situation, external cephalic version should be attempted.

 

Management of Transverse lie –

 

 

Absolute Contraindications of ECV:

 

  • Placenta Previa
  • Contracted Pelvis
  • Multiple Pregnancy
  • Hyperextended head
  • Uterine Anomaly
  • Dead fetus
  • Distressed fetus
  • Denied consent

 

Complications of ECV:

 

  • Abruption
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Preterm labour.
  • Fetal distress.
  • Cord presentation or prolapse
  • Entangling of the cord around the fetus.
  • Isoimmunization in Rh-negative mothers due to feto-maternal transfusion.
  • Induction of labor is contraindicated in Transverse lie.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: While a cesarean section is the best and safest method of delivery in cases of persistent transverse or oblique lie, it is not the first-line management in this situation where ECV can be attempted.

 

Option C. Expectant management: Waiting for spontaneous correction is not recommended at 36 weeks with a transverse lie, as it may not occur, and could lead to complications.

 

Option D. Induction of labor: Inducing labor in a transverse lie position is contraindicated as it can lead to complications such as cord prolapse and obstructed labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External cephalic version should be attempted between 36 and 37 weeks of gestation for a fetus in a transverse lie if there are no contraindications.

questions.text: Non-immune hydrops is seen in all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human immunodeficiency virus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Non-immune hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in at least two fetal compartments, such as ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or skin edema, not caused by maternal alloimmunization.
  • Pathogenesis includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability. These factors can lead to the development of fetal effusions and anasarca (generalized edema).
  • Infectious causes of non-immune hydrops include parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, and Lyme disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus: This virus can cause non-immune hydrops due to fetal infection leading to systemic inflammation and multiorgan failure.

 

Option C. Syphilis: A congenital infection with syphilis can cause severe fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Parvovirus B19: This virus is a well-known cause of non-immune hydrops due to its predilection for infecting red blood cell precursors, leading to severe fetal anemia and hydrops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is not a cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 926

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breasts were found to be poorly developed, vagina was present. Ultrasound revealed a normal uterus, but gonads weren't detected. Further evaluation done showed 46XY karyotype. The most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Swyer's syndrome

 

The clinical scenario described is indicative of Swyer syndrome, which is characterized by a 46XY karyotype and gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Key points about Swyer syndrome:

 

  • Swyer syndrome, also known as 46XY gonadal dysgenesis, is a condition where individuals with an XY karyotype present phenotypically as females.
  • These patients have a normal uterus and vagina but lack functioning gonads, which are often termed "streak gonads."
  • Because of gonadal dysgenesis, these individuals do not secrete testosterone or Antimullerian Hormone (AMH), leading to the development of female genital organs and phenotype.
  • Clinical presentation includes primary amenorrhea, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, and female external genitalia despite a 46XY karyotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Also known as testicular feminization syndrome, individuals have a 46XY karyotype but are phenotypically female with well-developed breasts and absent axillary and pubic hair. The gonads are testes, and there is no uterus.

 

Option B. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45XO karyotype. Patients typically present with short stature, shield chest, cubitus valgus, poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics, and streak ovaries.

 

Option C. True hermaphrodite: True hermaphrodites have both ovarian and testicular tissue present, which is not consistent with the clinical scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Swyer syndrome (46XY gonadal dysgenesis) is a condition where individuals with a 46XY karyotype present phenotypically as females with primary amenorrhea, poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics, and a normal uterus but lack functioning gonads.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 33446, Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg373

questions.text: What should be the ideal percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4%

 

Explanation:

 

  • Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.
  • As per the strict criteria, >4% normal forms of morphology must be present.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis is >4% according to WHO 2010 criteria.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg442, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg232

choices.text: Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends
﻿﻿﻿At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding late decelerations? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

 

Explanation:

 

Incorrect. Late decelerations are defined by a decrease in fetal heart rate that is typically more than 15 beats per minute below the baseline and is not defined by a specific frequency above baseline. The characteristic depth and timing of the deceleration are more important than the number of beats or frequency above the baseline.

 

Late decelerations in fetal heart rate patterns are important indicators of fetal well-being and uteroplacental function. late decelerations are indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency. Understanding their characteristics is crucial for accurate assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends: Correct. Late decelerations start after the peak of the uterine contraction and end after the contraction has concluded. This delayed onset and resolution are key features.

 

Option B. They are smooth and gradual: Correct. Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth and gradual decline in fetal heart rate (FHR).

 

Option D. Not associated with accelerations: Correct. Late decelerations are not typically associated with accelerations. This differentiates them from other types of decelerations, such as early decelerations, which can be accompanied by accelerations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth, gradual decline in fetal heart rate that begins after the peak of a uterine contraction and returns to baseline after the contraction ends, and they are not defined by beats above baseline or associated with accelerations.

 

Ref: Page 693, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Fetal lung fluid
Maternal plasma

questions.text: Major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal urine

 

Explanation:

 

  • Fetal urine production begins from 8-11 weeks period of gestation
  • In the first trimester, amniotic fluid is generally composed of extracellular fluid secreted across the amnion via trans membranous flow; across the fetal vessels on placental surface via intramembranous flow; and via transcutaneous flow across fetal skin.
  • Fetal urine is the major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal skin: While fetal skin does contribute to amniotic fluid in the first trimester through transcutaneous flow, it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.

 

Option C. Fetal lung fluid: Fetal lung fluid contributes to the amniotic fluid but not as significantly as fetal urine post 20 weeks.

 

Option D. Maternal plasma: Maternal plasma contributes indirectly to amniotic fluid via transmembranous flow, but it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal urine is the major contributor to amniotic fluid volume post 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A woman with a history of painful genital ulcers 1 year back has a neonate of 1 week who has lesions on face and body with neurological symptoms. What is the likely infection? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus)

 

The question presents a scenario where a woman has a history of painful genital ulcers and has given birth to a neonate who now exhibits lesions on the face and body along with neurological symptoms. This clinical picture strongly suggests a neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is known to cause painful genital ulcers in adults. The virus can remain latent in the body and reactivate later. During pregnancy or delivery, HSV can be transmitted to the neonate, particularly during vaginal delivery if there are active lesions or viral shedding. Neonatal HSV infection can present with vesicular lesions on the skin, eyes, and mouth, and it may also involve the central nervous system, leading to neurological symptoms. Neonatal HSV infection is a serious condition that requires prompt antiviral treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Incorrect because it does not cause painful genital ulcers in the mother or the described symptoms in the neonate.

 

Option B. Varicella: Incorrect because, although it can cause skin lesions in neonates, it is not linked with a history of painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Option D. CMV: Incorrect because CMV can cause congenital infections with neurological symptoms, but it is not associated with painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A history of painful genital ulcers in the mother, especially when associated with neonatal lesions and neurological symptoms, is highly suggestive of neonatal HSV infection. HSV is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent severe outcomes in the neonate.

questions.text: Outlet forceps is known as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wrigley forceps

 

 

 

Wrigley forceps, also known as outlet forceps, are short obstetrical forceps used during the final stages of labor when the fetal head is at or near the perineum, typically at +3 station. These forceps are designed for use when the fetal head is low in the pelvis and the internal rotation is either complete or nearly complete (45 degrees or less).

 

Wrigley forceps are specifically used to assist in the delivery when the head is on the perineum and crowning is imminent. They are shorter than other types of forceps, making them suitable for this stage of labor where minimal traction is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Piper forceps: These are specialized forceps used to deliver the aftercoming head in a breech presentation.

 

 

Option C. Das forceps: These are used in mid-cavity deliveries and are longer and heavier compared to Wrigley forceps.

 

 

Option D. Kielland forceps: These are rotational forceps used for correcting malpositioned fetal heads, especially in cases requiring significant rotation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wrigley forceps, also known as outlet forceps, are used during the final stage of labor when the fetal head is at or near the perineum, specifically at +3 station, to assist in delivery.

questions.text: Which procedure amongst the following has the highest probability of ureteric injury? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wertheim's hysterectomy

 

Ureteric injury is most associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to the radical nature of the procedure. Wertheim's hysterectomy, also known as radical hysterectomy, involves extensive dissection and removal of not only the uterus but also the surrounding tissues, including the parametria and the upper part of the vagina. This extensive dissection increases the risk of ureteric injury.

 

However, it's important to note that while Wertheim's hysterectomy carries a higher individual risk for ureteric injury due to its radical nature, the most common cause of ureteric injury overall is abdominal hysterectomy, simply because it is the most commonly performed type of hysterectomy.

 

The overall incidence of ureteric injury in all pelvic operations is about 0.5-1%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abdominal hysterectomy: Although it is the most common cause of ureteric injury due to its high frequency, the individual risk per procedure is lower than that of Wertheim's hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Vaginal hysterectomy: This procedure has a lower risk of ureteric injury compared to abdominal and Wertheim's hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Anterior colporrhaphy: This procedure, which is used to repair the anterior vaginal wall, has a much lower risk of ureteric injury compared to hysterectomy procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureteric injury is most associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to the extensive dissection involved in the procedure.

 

The risk of ureteric injury is highest with a radical hysterectomy followed laparoscopic or robotic hysterectomy followed by abdominal hysterectomy and least risk is with vaginal hysterectomy

 

Ref: TeLinde’s Operative gynecology 12th edition

choices.text: Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months
Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months of starting primary therapy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the treatment of recurrent ovarian cancer? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months  of starting primary therapy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Platinum-refractory disease: This includes women who progress during primary chemotherapy. It has the worst prognosis, as these patients do not respond to platinum-based chemotherapy at all.
  • Platinum-resistant disease: This includes women who relapse within 6 months of completing primary therapy. Bevacizumab has been approved for the treatment of platinum-resistant disease due to its ability to inhibit angiogenesis, which is crucial for tumor growth and metastasis.
  • Platinum-sensitive disease: This includes women who relapse more than 6 months after completing primary therapy. These patients are considered to have a better prognosis and are treated with a platinum-based combination such as carboplatin and paclitaxel or gemcitabine.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Platinum resistant if recurrence > 12 months: This statement is incorrect. If the recurrence occurs more than 12 months after treatment, it is considered platinum-sensitive, not resistant.

 

Option B. Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months: This statement is not a recognized classification. The classification focuses on the 6-month mark to distinguish between resistant and sensitive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Platinum-sensitive recurrent ovarian cancer is characterized by a recurrence occurring more than 6 months after completing primary therapy.

 

 

Ref: Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15th edition pg 1387

questions.text: Which of the following procedures, this instrument is used for? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endometrial Sampling

 

Explanation:

 

Given image is for Pipelle aspirator, used to obtain endometrial sample for biopsy.

 

Endometrial aspiration is an OPD procedure, it doesn’t require cervical dilation. It’s painless, but it is a blind procedure, so tissue can be missed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilatation and curettage: It may be diagnostic or therapeutic. It involves mechanical dilatation using metallic dilators such as Hegars followed by curettage of the cavity using a curette.

 

Option B. Cervical sampling:  It may be used for screening or for cytohormonal study.  Ayres spatula made of wood or plastic may be used for collection of material from the Squamo-columnar junction. Endocervical sampling can be performed using a cytobrush or with a moist tip applicator. A cervical biopsy is used for confirmation of diagnosis.

 

Option D. Hysterosalpingography: It is a radiological procedure using contrast to assess tubal patency and tubal and uterine anatomy using sequential x-rays. Either water soluble dye diatrizoate (renografin 60) or low viscosity oil-based dye ethiodized oil (ethiodol) may be introduced slowly (5-10 ml) using an HSG cannula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pipelle aspirator is used to obtain endometrial sample for biopsy

 

Ref: D. C. Dutta’s Textbook of gynaecology 6th Edition page 120, 604, 110

questions.text: What is the age group distribution for vulval cancer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 55-85 years

 

55-85 years: Correct. The majority of vulval cancer cases are diagnosed in women aged 55 to 85 years. The average age of diagnosis is between 60 and 65 years.

 

Vulval cancer primarily affects older women, and its age distribution is as follows:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Not age specific: Incorrect. Vulval cancer is not "not age specific"; it is specifically associated with an older age group.

 

Option B. 35-55 years: Incorrect. Although vulval cancer can occur in younger women, the majority of cases are diagnosed in the older age group, typically between 55 and 85 years.

 

Option D. Both of the above: Incorrect. The age distribution for vulval cancer does not cover both age groups mentioned (35-55 years and 55-85 years) equally. The more accurate distribution is predominantly in the 55-85 years range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulval cancer predominantly affects women aged 55 to 85 years, with the average diagnosis occurring between 60 and 65 years.

 

Ref: Page no 333, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Identify this contraceptive: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lippe’s loop

 

Lippe’s loop is a type of non-medicated, first-generation intrauterine device (IUD). It is a plastic coiled device that was widely used in the 1950s and 1960s. It is characterized by its distinctive S-shaped loops, as seen in the image provided.

 

The Lippe's loop does not contain any medication or metal, distinguishing it from other types of IUDs like the Multiload, Mirena, and Copper T 380A, which have additional features or materials to enhance their contraceptive effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiload: This option is incorrect. The Multiload IUD has serrated edges and typically includes copper wiring on the stem to enhance contraceptive effectiveness.

 

 

Option C. Mirena: This is incorrect. Mirena is a hormonal IUD that releases levonorgestrel and appears white in color. It does not have the coiled shape seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Copper T 380A: This option is incorrect. The Copper T 380A IUD has copper wires on the branches and the main stem, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lippe’s loop is a non-medicated, coiled plastic IUD from the first generation of intrauterine devices.

questions.text: Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amniotic fluid embolism

 

  • The given clinical scenario with a diagnosis of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) points to amniotic fluid embolism as the most likely etiology.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism presents as 
    • hemodynamic and respiratory compromise, along with DIC.
    • Usually, it presents during the late stages of labor or immediate postpartum.
    • Gasping for air, seizures, and cardiorespiratory arrest are other features.

 

Diagnostic criteria for amniotic fluid embolism include:

 

  • Sudden onset cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt DIC
  • Onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta
  • No fever ≥38°C

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postpartum haemorrhage: This will present as vaginal bleeding followed by collapse/ DIC

 

Option C. Eclampsia: This will present as seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: This will present as cardiac failure following delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to amniotic fluid embolism.

choices.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21
It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about non-invasive prenatal testing? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21

 

Explanation:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening tool, not a diagnostic tool. It uses cell-free fetal DNA circulating in the maternal serum to screen for certain genetic conditions, including trisomies 13, 18, and 21.

 

NIPT is not used for diagnosis but for screening. It has high sensitivity (about 99%) for detecting trisomies 21, 18, and 13, but positive results must be confirmed with diagnostic tests such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum: Correct. NIPT uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum to assess the risk of certain genetic conditions in the fetus.

 

Option C. It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation: Correct. NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation, when there is enough fetal DNA in the maternal blood for accurate analysis.

 

Option D. It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment: Correct. NIPT is often done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment, which helps determine gestational age and detect multiple pregnancies or major anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening test for aneuploidy using cell-free fetal DNA in maternal serum, typically performed after 10 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page 890, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Extravasation into venous system
﻿﻿﻿Bilateral cornual block

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

 

The given HSG (hysterosalpingogram) film shows bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes, suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx. Hydrosalpinx is typically caused by the end result of repeated mild endo-salpingitis (inflammation of the fallopian tubes) by pyogenic organisms of low virulence but highly irritant.

 

The organisms involved include:

 

  • Staphylococcus
  • E. coli
  • Gonococcus
  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

During the initial infection, the fimbriae become edematous and in-drawn with the serous surface, adhering together to produce closure of the abdominal ostium. The uterine ostium gets closed by congestion. This results in the secretion being pent up, causing the tube to distend. The distension is marked more in the ampullary region than in the more rigid isthmus. As the mesosalpinx is fixed, the resultant distension makes the tube curled and look 'retort'-shaped. The wall is smooth and shiny, containing clear fluid inside, which is usually sterile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extravasation into venous system: This would show contrast leaking into the venous system and not confined to the Fallopian tubes.

 

Option C. Normal HSG: A normal HSG would show patent Fallopian tubes without distension or blockage.

 

Option D. Bilateral cornual block: This would show blockage at the cornua (the point where the Fallopian tubes enter the uterine cavity) without the dilated, fluid-filled appearance seen in hydrosalpinx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrosalpinx is characterized by bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes filled with clear fluid, often due to repeated mild infections causing obstruction and distension.

 

Ref: Page no 171, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyometra

 

Explanation:

 

Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) involves infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract, which can include the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries. PID can result from sexually transmitted infections and, if left untreated, can lead to several serious complications.

 

Complications of long-standing pelvic inflammation include:

 

  1. Infertility: Due to damage to the fallopian tubes and the resulting adhesions, which can block the passage of eggs from the ovaries to the uterus.
  2. Ectopic pregnancy: Scarring of the fallopian tubes can cause a fertilized egg to implant outside the uterus, most commonly in the tubes.
  3. Pyometra: Accumulation of pus within the uterine cavity, often due to obstruction of the cervical canal combined with chronic infection.
  4. Dyspareunia: Pain during sexual intercourse, often due to adhesions and chronic pelvic pain.
  5. Chronic pelvic pain: Persistent pain in the lower abdomen, which can be severe and debilitating.
  6. Frozen pelvis: Severe adhesions can cause the pelvic organs to become fixed in place, leading to significant pain and dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine polyposis: Uterine polyposis involves the development of benign polyps within the endometrial cavity and is not typically a direct result of PID.

 

Option C. Pseudocyesis: Pseudocyesis, or false pregnancy, is a psychological condition where a woman believes she is pregnant and may exhibit pregnancy symptoms, but is not related to PID.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: Endometrial hyperplasia refers to the thickening of the endometrial lining due to excess estrogen stimulation and is not a direct consequence of PID.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can lead to serious complications such as infertility, ectopic pregnancy, chronic pelvic pain, and pyometra.

 

Ref: Page no 155, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High estrogen


Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited primarily by high estrogen levels. Although prolactin, an anterior pituitary hormone, is responsible for stimulating milk production (lactogenesis), high levels of estrogen and progesterone during pregnancy prevent the secretion of milk. Estrogen promotes the development of the mammary glands but suppresses milk production. After childbirth, the levels of estrogen and progesterone drop, which allows prolactin to initiate and sustain milk secretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low luteinizing hormone: Incorrect. Luteinizing hormone (LH) is not directly involved in the regulation of milk production. The primary inhibitors are estrogen and progesterone.

 

Option C. Human somatomammotropin: Incorrect. Human somatomammotropin (also known as human placental lactogen) supports breast development and promotes milk production but does not inhibit it.

 

Option D. Low thyroid-stimulating hormone: Incorrect. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is not a primary factor in inhibiting milk production during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:


High estrogen levels inhibit milk production during pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page no 173, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 6th edition

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman complains of leakage of urine on straining and coughing. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stress urinary incontinence

 

Explanation:

 

Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) occurs when there is involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as straining, coughing, sneezing, or exercising. This condition is often due to weakness of the pelvic floor muscles and the urethral sphincter, which fail to properly support the bladder and urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urge urinary incontinence: This type of incontinence is characterized by a sudden and intense urge to urinate, followed by involuntary leakage of urine. It is commonly associated with an overactive bladder.

 

Option C. Mixed urinary incontinence: This occurs when a person experiences symptoms of both stress and urge urinary incontinence.

 

Option D. Overflow incontinence: This type occurs when the bladder fails to empty completely, leading to leakage of small amounts of urine. It is often associated with bladder outlet obstruction or neurological conditions affecting bladder function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stress urinary incontinence is diagnosed when an individual experiences leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as straining or coughing, due to weakened pelvic floor muscles and urethral sphincter.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:

 

  • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor: While acyclovir is appropriate for treating HSV, inducing labor is not recommended due to the high risk of neonatal infection with vaginal delivery in the presence of active primary HSV lesions.

 

Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Spontaneous vaginal delivery poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can lead to severe complications and high mortality. This is not recommended in the case of primary genital HSV.

 

Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Antiviral treatment is necessary, but normal vaginal delivery is not recommended due to the high risk of transmitting HSV to the neonate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of primary genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at term, the best treatment option is to start antiviral therapy and plan for an elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes infection.

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) External anal sphincter

 

Explanation

 

  • Obstetrical Anal Sphincter Injuries (OASIS) include third and fourth-degree lacerations.
  • Third-degree lacerations involve the external anal sphincter:
    • 3A: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3B: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3C: Both the external and internal anal sphincter torn.
  • Fourth-degree lacerations extend to the rectal mucosa.
  • In the scenario mentioned, the episiotomy has extended backward beyond the perineal body, likely damaging the anal sphincter and potentially the anal mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ischiocavernosus: This muscle is located more laterally and is less likely to be involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Option C: Bulbospongiosus: This muscle is located in the perineal body and is usually affected by a standard episiotomy, but not specifically by a backward extension beyond the perineal body.

 

Option D: Urethral sphincter: This sphincter is located anteriorly and is not involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where an episiotomy extends backward beyond the perineal body, the external anal sphincter is the structure most likely to be injured.

 

Ref: Page no 1307, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: It has one artery and two veins
It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly
Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies
Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the umbilical cord? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It has one artery and two veins

 

Explanation:

 

  • The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.
  • This 3 vessel umbilical cord appears as a “mickey-mouse sign” manner on the ultrasound finding
  • The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus and the 2 umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly: Wharton’s jelly is the gelatinous material surrounding the umbilical cord which protects it from external forces

 

Option C. Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies: A single umbilical artery is the most common anomaly in an umbilical cord.

 

It is associated with congenital anomalies such as genitourinary and cardiac anomalies

 

It may also be associated with Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome) and other chromosomal anomalies

 

Option D. Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm: The average length of the umbilical cord is 50 cm

 

Educational objective:

 

The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.

 

Ref: Page no 44, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus
Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

questions.text: A 27y primigravida has just delivered. When removing the placenta, uterine inversion is noted. What is the next immediate step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

 

Explanation:

 

Uterine inversion is a rare but serious obstetric emergency that occurs when the uterus turns inside out after delivery. Immediate management is crucial to prevent severe hemorrhage and shock. The next immediate step in the management of uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached. This is done to quickly restore the uterus to its normal position and reduce the risk of continued bleeding and shock.

 

 

After manually repositioning the uterus, the healthcare provider should maintain the position by keeping a fist inside the uterus and administering uterotonic agents such as oxytocin to promote uterine contractions, which help to keep the uterus in place and reduce bleeding. The placenta should only be removed after the uterus has been repositioned successfully.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shift to OT immediately: While surgical intervention may be required if manual repositioning fails, the initial step is to manually reposition the uterus.

 

Option B. Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to increased bleeding and is not recommended.

 

Option D. O'Sullivan's hydrostatic maneuver: This maneuver involves using fluid pressure to reposition the uterus and is used if manual repositioning fails. It is not the immediate next step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate step in managing uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached, followed by administration of uterotonic agents to maintain the uterus in its correct position.

questions.text: The drug used in chemoradiation in cervical cancer:  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cisplatin

 

In the treatment of cervical cancer, chemoradiation is a standard approach, particularly for stages beyond 2A where surgery may not be feasible.

 

Chemoradiation combines chemotherapy and radiation therapy to enhance the effectiveness of treatment.

 

Cisplatin is the drug of choice because it acts as a radiosensitizer. This means. that cisplatin makes the cancer cells more sensitive to the effects of radiation therapy, thereby increasing the overall efficacy of the treatment. The standard regimen involves administering cisplatin concurrently with external beam radiotherapy, and this may be followed by internal beam radiotherapy to maximize treatment impact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide: Used in various chemotherapy regimens but not as a primary radiosensitizer in cervical cancer chemoradiation.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Used in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases but not primarily in cervical cancer chemoradiation.

 

Option C. Actinomycin D: Used in the treatment of certain pediatric cancers and other malignancies but not as a standard radiosensitizer in cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cisplatin is the preferred drug used in chemoradiation for cervical cancer because it acts as a radiosensitizer, enhancing the effectiveness of radiation therapy.

choices.text: Previous manual removal of placenta

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered as a factor for a high-risk pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Previous manual removal of placenta

 

Explanation:

 

Previous manual removal of the placenta does not automatically categorize a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk. High-risk pregnancies are characterized by various factors that may complicate the pregnancy or pose risks to the mother and fetus. These factors include existing health conditions, certain lifestyle factors, age-related risks, and specific pregnancy conditions.

 

High-risk pregnancy factors according to the NIH include:

 

  1. Existing health conditions:
    • Hypertension
    • Diabetes
    • Autoimmune diseases
    • PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome)
    • Thyroid disorders
    • Obesity
    • HIV
    • Anemia
    • Uterine fibroids
  2. Age:
    • Adolescence
    • First-time pregnancy at age >35 years
  3. Lifestyle factors:
    • Alcohol consumption
    • Smoking
    • Drug use
  4. Pregnancy conditions:
    • Multiple pregnancy
    • Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)
    • Pre-eclampsia
    • Previous preterm birth
    • Congenital or chromosomal anomalies
    • Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios
    • Rh iso-immunization
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obesity: Obesity is a significant factor for a high-risk pregnancy as it is associated with various complications such as gestational diabetes, pre-eclampsia, and increased risk of cesarean delivery.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios, which is an excessive amount of amniotic fluid, can lead to complications such as preterm labor and fetal malformations, making it a high-risk condition.

 

Option C. Anemia: Anemia during pregnancy can affect the health of both the mother and the fetus, leading to conditions such as preterm birth and low birth weight, thus categorizing it as high-risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Previous manual removal of the placenta is not considered a factor for categorizing a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk.

 

Ref: https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/high-risk

questions.text: Seminal vesicles and vas deferens would be bilaterally absent congenitally in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystic fibrosis

 

  • Seminal vesicles and vas deferens would be bilaterally absent, congenitally in cystic fibrosis. This is known as the congenital bilateral absence of vas deference (CBAVD) and is a causes of obstructive azoospermia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome (47 XXY) accounts or 1 to 2 percent of male infertility cases. Classically, these men are tall, undervirilized, and have gynecomastia and small, rm testes

 

Option C. Kallman syndrome: This is a form of congenital hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism with anosmia. It presents as primary amenorrhoea in women and with male infertility in men

 

Option D. Kartagener syndrome: Kartagener's syndrome is a rare, autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder comprising the triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. The basic problem lies in the defective movement of cilia, leading to recurrent chest infections, ear/nose/throat symptoms, and infertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis is associated with congenital bilateral absence of the seminal vesicles and vas deferens, leading to obstructive azoospermia.

 

Ref: Page no 229, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Raise in ESR during pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibrinogen

 

Explanation:

 

Pregnancy is characterized as a hypercoagulable state, and several changes occur in the coagulation system during pregnancy. One of the significant changes is the increase in fibrinogen levels, which leads to a rise in the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Fibrinogen Levels: During pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase by approximately 50%, from 200-400 mg/dL to 300-600 mg/dL. This rise in fibrinogen contributes significantly to the increased ESR.
  • ESR: The ESR can increase up to four times during pregnancy due to the increased levels of fibrinogen and globulin.
  • Platelet Count: There may be a slight fall in platelet count during pregnancy, commonly due to gestational thrombocytopenia, which is caused by hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. This condition usually has no adverse effect on pregnancy and is often observed in the third trimester.
  • Coagulation Factors: There is an increase in the plasma levels of several coagulation factors, including factors 1 (fibrinogen), 2, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Factors 2, 5, and 12 remain unchanged or mildly increased, while factors 11 and 13 are slightly decreased.
  • Clotting Time: Clotting time is generally unaffected by pregnancy.
  • Anti-Thrombin III: Levels of anti-thrombin III decrease during pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Albumin levels typically decrease during pregnancy due to hemodilution, and they do not contribute to the rise in ESR.

 

Option B. Platelet: Platelet count may slightly decrease due to gestational thrombocytopenia, but this does not contribute to the rise in ESR.

 

Option D. Anti-thrombin antibody: This is not a relevant factor in the context of ESR increase during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The rise in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) during pregnancy is primarily due to the increased levels of fibrinogen.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg59

choices.text: Need for blood transfusion
Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS
Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS
Risk of peripartum hysterectomy

questions.text: A 39-year-old G6P2L1A3 presents with a history of previous 2 LSCS with PAS. What will you NOT counsel her about? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), the main risks include bleeding requiring transfusion, bladder injury, and possibly peripartum hysterectomy. Bowel injury is less commonly associated with PAS unless extreme or exceptional surgical complications occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Need for blood transfusion: It is common to counsel about the need for blood transfusion due to the high risk of hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS: Bladder injury is a significant risk if the placenta invades the bladder area.

 

Option D. Risk of peripartum hysterectomy: Peripartum hysterectomy may be necessary if the placenta is inseparable from the uterus.

 

Educational objective:

 

When counseling a patient with a history of previous cesarean sections and PAS, focus on the more likely complications such as significant bleeding, bladder injury, and the possibility of needing a hysterectomy, rather than bowel injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the vertex presentation with complete flexion attitude of head? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter

 

Explanation:

 

Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with a complete flexion attitude of the head.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suboccipito-frontal diameter:

 

  • This diameter measures about 10.5 cm and is seen when the head is only partially flexed.
  • It is not the smallest diameter and is not optimal for vertex presentations with complete flexion.

 

Option C. Occipito-frontal diameter:

 

  • This diameter measures approximately 11.5 cm and is seen in cases where the head is in a neutral position, neither fully flexed nor extended.
  • It is larger and more difficult for the passage of the fetal head through the birth canal.

 

Option D. Occipito-posterior position:

 

  • This is not a diameter but a fetal position where the back of the fetal head is directed towards the mother's back.
  • This position often leads to a more difficult labor and is associated with different presenting diameters, depending on the degree of head flexion or extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with complete flexion of the fetal head, facilitating easier passage through the birth canal.

 

Ref: Page no   92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: Nugent score is for diagnosis of? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis


The Nugent score is a microbiological scoring system used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis (BV). It is based on the examination of a vaginal smear under a microscope to evaluate the presence and quantity of bacterial morphotypes, particularly Lactobacilli, Gardnerella, and Mobiluncus. A high Nugent score indicates a decrease in normal Lactobacilli and an increase in pathogenic bacteria, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. This scoring system provides a more objective and standardized diagnosis compared to clinical criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomoniasis:  is incorrect because trichomoniasis is diagnosed through wet mount microscopy, culture, or molecular tests, which detect Trichomonas vaginalis, not by the Nugent score.

 

Option C. Candidiasis : is incorrect as it refers to yeast infections typically diagnosed by identifying Candida species on wet mount, KOH preparation, or fungal cultures, not using the Nugent score.

 

Option D. Chlamydia: is incorrect since Chlamydia is diagnosed through nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), culture, or antigen detection, not by the Nugent scoring system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nugent score is used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. It is a microbiological scoring system where the vaginal smear is analyzed for the number of lactobacilli and abnormal bacteria. The clinical scoring system for bacterial vaginosis is the Amsel's criteria, which includes the whiff test, clue cells, alkaline pH, and whitish discharge.

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day she came back with fever, tachycardia and seizures. Fundus showed papilledema with no focal deficits. Diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cortical vein thrombosis

 

  • The given clinical situation likely suggests Cortical Vein Thrombosis.
  • Cortical Vein thrombosis
    • Risk factors:
      • Pregnancy and puerperium
      • Oral contraceptives
      • Pro thrombotic conditions
    • Clinical presentation
      • Highly variable
      • Headache is the most common symptom.
      • With or without
      • Vomiting
      • Papilledema
      • Focal deficits
    • Investigation
      • Brain MRI with MR venography - most sensitive
      • CT - normal in 30 % of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Subarachnoid hemorrhage unlikely as there are no focal deficits

 

Option B. Meningitis: Meningitis would have presented with neck rigidity / photophobia and early papilledema goes against acute meningitis.

 

Option C. Acute Migraine: Acute Migraine does not present with seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cortical/ Cerebral vein thrombosis should be thought of in a patient with headache and seizures/ other neurological deficits following delivery

questions.text: In which of the following infections do both partners need to be treated? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichomoniasis

 

Explanation:

 

Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. In cases of trichomoniasis, it is essential to treat both the infected individual and their sexual partner(s) to prevent reinfection and to control the spread of the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial vaginosis (BV): Although BV is associated with an increased risk of acquiring STIs, it is not classified as an STI itself. Therefore, routine treatment of sexual partners is not recommended.

 

Option B. Candidiasis: This is typically caused by an overgrowth of Candida species, commonly Candida albicans, and is not considered an STI. Treating the sexual partner is not usually necessary unless the partner has symptoms of candidiasis.

 

Option D. Genital TB: This is primarily spread through hematogenous (blood) or lymphatic routes rather than sexual transmission. Partners are not treated unless they are also diagnosed with genital tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For trichomoniasis, both partners need to be treated to prevent reinfection and control the spread of the disease.

choices.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, the cervix is fully dilated with the head at station 0 with molding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-transverse position.
