The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lower segment cesarean section

 

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of deep transverse arrest (DTA)
  • There are features of CPD (Caput 2 + and moulding 2+)
  • Hence, a lower segment cesarean section is carried out for the management of this patient.
  • In deep transverse arrest
    • The sagittal suture is placed in the transverse bispinous diameter.
    • There is no descent of the head despite good uterine contractions
    • The cervix is fully dilated
    • If the pelvis is adequate, application of ventouse or manual rotation and forces application can be tried. (Vacuum is preferred)
    • If signs of CDP/ obstruction: Cesarean section is done

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid pelvic forceps: Mid pelvic forceps: Cannot be applied in this scenario as there are features of obstructed labor with deep transverse arrest

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum is an option in deep transverse arrest but only if there is no CPD. With caput ++ and moulding ++, there is likely an element of CPD and obstruction and hence vacuum should not be used

 

Option C. Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor: Waiting and watching is not an option as the patient is already showing features of obstructed labor and she has already been in 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours (upper limit for 2nd stage of labor in primi is 3h and in multi is 2h)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of deep transverse arrest with features of CPD, a lower segment cesarean section is the appropriate management to prevent complications and ensure safe delivery.

 

Ref: Page 661, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina
Complete vaginal atresia

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the OPD with a history of primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain. Perineal examination reveals a bulge protruding from the vagina. Identify the cause of this presentation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  •  Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain is suggestive of an obstructive cause.
  • O/e a bulge seen protruding from the vagina is suggestive of an imperforate hymen.
  • This classically presents as a bluish bulge distending the hymen.
  • The bulge (hematocolpos) is felt along the entire length of the vagina on doing a PR examination
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision and drainage of hamatocolpos is done.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Transverse septum in the proximal vagina: This also will present as primary amenorrhoea with cyclical abdominal pain as the menstrual blood accumulates inside. But on examination, the bulge wont be seen at the introitus as the obstruction is higher up in a proximal or high transverse vaginal septum.

 

Option B. Complete vaginal atresia: In Complete vaginal atresia, also the symptoms of primary amenorrhoea and cyclical abdominal pain will be present, but again the obstruction will be high. There will be hematometra. Local examination will reveal an absent vagina or a bling ending vagina.

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: In cervical agenesis, again there will be hematometra, I.e. the obstruction is higher up and there will not ne any bulge seen on local exam.

 

Educational Objective

 

Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain and a bulge protruding from the vagina is indicative of an imperforate hymen, requiring cruciate incision and drainage of hematocolpos.

 

Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 53-year-old postmenopausal lady is detected by endometrial hyperplasia with atypia what is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

 

Postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia should be offered a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to the very high risk of progression to malignancy. This approach effectively removes the source of hyperplasia and eliminates the potential for malignant transformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progesterone: High dose Progesterones can be used to manage endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, but this is not the recommended approach for atypical hyperplasia in postmenopausal women.

 

Option C. Mirena: The LNG-IUS (Mirena) can be recommended for those who want to preserve fertility and for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. However, it is not suitable for postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure may be used for diagnostic purposes but is not treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia in postmenopausal women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmenopausal women with atypical endometrial hyperplasia should undergo a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.

 

Ref: Page no 329, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Laparoscopic tubal ligation

questions.text: Which of the following is an irreversible method of contraception? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopic tubal ligation

 

Contraceptive methods can be classified into temporary (reversible) and permanent (irreversible) methods.

 

  • Permanent Methods (Irreversible):
    • Laparoscopic Tubal Ligation: This is a surgical procedure where the fallopian tubes are cut, tied, or sealed to prevent pregnancy permanently. It is considered an irreversible method of contraception as it is intended to be a permanent solution for women who do not wish to have more children.
  • Temporary Methods (Reversible):
    • Copper-T (Intrauterine Device - IUD): A long-term but reversible method that can be removed when pregnancy is desired.
    • Implanon (Subdermal Contraceptive Implant): A long-term reversible method that can be removed to restore fertility.
    • LNG-IUD (Levonorgestrel Intrauterine Device): Another long-term reversible method that can be removed when pregnancy is desired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent (irreversible) method of contraception.

 

Ref: Page no 611, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Infundibulum
Ampulla
Isthmus

questions.text: Identify the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ampulla

 

Explanation

 

Ectopic pregnancy refers to implantation occurring outside the endometrial cavity.

 

Sites of implantation

 

 

Uterine (.5%) such as cervical (1%), caesarean scar ectopic <1%)

 

Management of tubal ectopic may be medical or surgical: medical management maybe considered if the patient is haemodynamically stable , foetal cardiac activity absent, beta HCG level less than 5000 , size of gestational sac less than 4 cm .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infundibulum: Accounts for 18% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Option C. Isthmus: Accounts for 25% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Option D. Interstitial portion: Accounts for 2% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Management of Tubal Ectopic Pregnancy:

 

Management may be medical or surgical:

 

  • Medical Management: Considered if the patient is hemodynamically stable, fetal cardiac activity is absent, beta HCG level is less than 5000, and the size of the gestational sac is less than 4 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ampulla of the fallopian tube is the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy, accounting for 55% of cases.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of obstetrics page 207

choices.text: Teratozoospermia
Asthenozoospermia
Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

questions.text: The results of semen analysis of a young male have been given below. What is the diagnosis? 5 million/mI concentration, 50% motility, 4% normal morphology? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oligospermia

 

Explanation:

 

The given semen analysis results show a sperm concentration of 5 million/mL, which is below the normal reference value set by the WHO. According to the WHO 2021 guidelines, a normal sperm concentration is 16 million/mL or higher. Therefore, this patient has oligospermia, which is defined as a sperm concentration of less than 15 million/mL. Counts below 5 million/mL are considered severe.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Oligospermia: Sperm concentration <15 million/mL. Severe oligospermia is when counts are <5 million/mL.
  • Teratozoospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology.
  • Asthenozoospermia: No motile sperms or diminished motility.
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: A combination of low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teratozoospermia: Teratozoospermia refers to abnormal sperm morphology. The morphology here is 4%, which is within the normal range according to WHO criteria.

 

Option C. Asthenozoospermia: Asthenozoospermia refers to reduced sperm motility. In this case, the motility is 50%, which is normal.

 

Option D. Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: This term describes a condition where there is a combination of low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology. In this case, only the sperm concentration is abnormal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of less than 15 million/mL, with counts below 5 million/mL considered severe. The given semen analysis results show oligospermia based on the sperm concentration of 5 million/mL.

 

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 442, Duttas textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg232

https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240030787

questions.text: Which of the following emergency contraceptive is used in India? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg


In India, Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is commonly used as an emergency contraceptive. This medication is effective when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. It works primarily by inhibiting or delaying ovulation, thus preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol 400 mcg: Incorrect. Misoprostol is used for medical abortion and does not serve as an emergency contraceptive.

 

Option B. Ethinyl estradiol 600 mcg: Incorrect. Ethinyl estradiol is used in combined oral contraceptive pills, but it is not commonly used alone for emergency contraception. The Yuzpe regimen, which includes ethynyl estradiol, is less commonly used compared to levonorgestrel.

 

Option C. Ulipristal 30 mg: Incorrect. Ulipristal acetate (30 mg) is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used as an emergency contraceptive, but it is not as widely available or commonly used in India as levonorgestrel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the emergency contraceptive used in India.

 

Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text: What would be the mode of delivery in images 1 and 2? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Image 1: Vaginal; image 2: Cesarean

 

In the provided images, the presentation of the twins is crucial in determining the mode of delivery:

 

  • Image 1: Both twins are in a cephalic presentation (head down), making it safe to consider vaginal delivery. Twin pregnancies where both twins present cephalically are usually managed vaginally unless there are other contraindications.
  • Image 2: The first twin (Twin A or the lowermost baby) is in a breech presentation, while the second twin is cephalic. In this scenario, a cesarean section is preferred to avoid complications associated with breech delivery, such as cord prolapse or head entrapment. Therefore, cesarean delivery is the recommended mode for this presentation.

 

Indications for cesarean in twin pregnancy:

 

  1. First twin is non-cephalic (breech or transverse presentation).
  2. Monochorionic, monoamniotic twins: Elective LSCS at around 34 weeks.
  3. Conjoined twins.
  4. Higher-order multiples (triplets, quadruplets, or more).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In twin pregnancies, the mode of delivery is determined primarily by the presentation of the first twin. If the first twin is cephalic, vaginal delivery can be considered, but if the first twin is non-cephalic (e.g., breech), a cesarean section is generally recommended.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument commonly used in obstetrics? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Episiotomy scissors

 

The instrument shown in the picture is an episiotomy scissors. The angulation in the scissor is designed to prevent the extension of a pelvic tear into the anal margins and to avoid obstetric anal sphincter injuries or complete perineal tears.

 

An episiotomy is not given routinely. Its use should be restricted to specific situations such as:

 

  • Macrosomia: When the baby is larger than average.
  • After coming head of breech: To facilitate the delivery of the head in a breech birth.
  • Instrumental delivery: When tools like forceps or vacuum are used to assist in delivery.
  • Shoulder dystocia: A delivery complication where the baby's shoulders get stuck.
  • Rigid perineum: Often seen in primigravida, where the perineum does not stretch easily.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mayo scissors: General-purpose surgical scissors used for cutting tissues.

 

Option B. Curved scissors: Scissors with a curved blade, used for various surgical procedures but not specifically for episiotomy.

 

Option C. Suture remover: Scissors designed specifically for removing sutures, not for performing an episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed to perform an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum to facilitate childbirth and prevent severe perineal tears. Their use is restricted to specific obstetric situations to avoid unnecessary complications.

 

Ref: Page no 755 Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: In POP Q staging, the reference point taken is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hymen

 

Explanation:

 

The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system is a standardized method for assessing and quantifying the severity of pelvic organ prolapse. The reference point in POP-Q staging is the hymen. All measurements in the POP-Q system are taken relative to the hymen, which serves as a fixed anatomical landmark.

 

 

The POP-Q system involves six specific points and three measurements:

 

 

Points:

 

Aa: A point on the anterior vaginal wall, 3 cm proximal to the hymen.

 

Ba: The most distal position of any part of the anterior vaginal wall.

 

C: The cervix or the vaginal cuff after hysterectomy.

 

Ap: A point on the posterior vaginal wall, 3 cm proximal to the hymen.

 

Bp: The most distal position of any part of the posterior vaginal wall.

 

D: The posterior fornix or the deepest part of the vaginal vault.

 

Measurements:

 

GH (Genital Hiatus): Distance from the external urethral meatus to the posterior hymen.

 

PB (Perineal Body): Distance from the posterior hymen to the mid-anal opening.

 

TVL (Total Vaginal Length): Distance from the hymen to the posterior fornix or vaginal apex.

 

Other 3 Options: Not used as a reference point in POP-Q staging.

 

Educational objective:

 

In the POP-Q system, the hymen is used as the reference point for all measurements and staging of pelvic organ prolapse.

choices.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.text: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest to her to relieve the pain? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extend knee and dorsiflex foot

 

Explanation:

 

To relieve leg cramps, the recommended technique is to:

 

  • Extend the knee: Straightening the leg helps in relieving tension and alleviating the cramp.
  • Dorsiflex the foot: This involves pulling the toes towards the shin, which stretches the calf muscles and helps in reducing the cramp.

 

Leg cramps during pregnancy are commonly caused by factors such as deficiencies in serum calcium, elevated serum phosphorus, or increased pressure on the leg veins. Stretching and adjusting the foot position can provide immediate relief from cramps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flex knee and dorsiflex foot: Flexing the knee while dorsiflexing the foot can help in some cases, but extending the knee is generally more effective in relieving cramp pain.

 

Option C. Extend knee and plantar flex foot: Plantar flexion (pointing the toes downward) can actually exacerbate calf cramps. Extending the knee while performing plantar flexion is not as effective for cramp relief.

 

Option D. Flex knee and plantar flex foot: Flexing the knee while performing plantar flexion will likely increase the cramp discomfort. This position may not provide effective relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To relieve leg cramps during pregnancy, extend the knee and dorsiflex the foot.

 

Ref: https://americanpregnancy.org/healthy-pregnancy/pregnancy-health-wellness/leg-cramps-during-pregnancy

choices.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prevention of RDS in premature baby

 

Explanation

 

Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4):

 

MgSO4 is used for several obstetric indications, including:

 

  1. Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the drug of choice for the prevention and treatment of seizures in eclampsia.
  2. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: It is used prophylactically to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.
  3. Tocolytic in Preterm Labor: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractions and delay preterm labor.
  4. Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks): MgSO4 is administered to provide neuroprotection for the fetus, reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders in preterm infants.

 

Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in Premature Baby:

 

  • MgSO4 does not play a role in the prevention of RDS. Instead, corticosteroids (such as betamethasone or dexamethasone) are used to accelerate fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of RDS in preterm babies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: MgSO4 is effectively used to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.

 

Option B. Prevention of Recurrent Seizures in Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the preferred treatment to prevent recurrent seizures in women with eclampsia.

 

Option D. Reducing Contractility of Uterus: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractility and delay preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are used for the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm babies.

 

Ref: Page 1860, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Head 1/5th palpable per abdomen
Head on perineum

questions.text: Outlet forceps is applied at what station? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Head on perineum

 

Outlet forceps are used when the fetal head is at the outlet of the birth canal, which means the head is visible at the perineum. This typically corresponds to a station of +4 or +5 depending on the system used, but "head on perineum" is the most accurate description.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head 1/5th palpable per abdomen: This indicates that the head is still relatively high in the birth canal and not at the outlet.

 

Option B. 0 station: This is when the fetal head is at the level of the ischial spines, which is too high for outlet forceps application.

 

Option C. +2 station: This indicates the fetal head is descending but not yet at the perineum. Low forceps might be used at this station, but not outlet forceps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Outlet forceps are applied when the fetal head is visible at the perineum, indicating it is at the outlet of the birth canal.
